Hi, I have a question on Proposition VI.1.8 of SGL; I cannot follow the proof.

The proposition says that if E\mathcal{E}E is an (elementary) topos such that all subterminal objects in it form a generating/separating family, and such that each subobject lattice SubE(E)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(E)SubE​(E) is a complete Boolean algebra, then E\mathcal{E}E satisfies the axiom of choice (i.e., every epimorphism in E\mathcal{E}E splits).

The proof in SGL first takes an arbitrary epimorphism p ⁣:X↠Ip\colon X\twoheadrightarrow Ip:X↠I, and tries to find its section. To do so, the authors consider the poset S⊆SubE(I)\mathcal{S}\subseteq \mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(I)S⊆SubE​(I) of all subobjects m ⁣:M↣Im\colon M\rightarrowtail Im:M↣I of III such that there exists a “partial section” on it, i.e., s ⁣:M↣Xs\colon M\rightarrowtail Xs:M↣X such that ps=mps=mps=m. Then they claim that S\mathcal{S}S has a maximal element, using completeness of SubE(I)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(I)SubE​(I) and (meta) Zorn’s lemma... But is it clear that every chain has an upper bound in S\mathcal{S}S? I think to do so one should consider the poset of partial sections, rather than the poset of domains of partial sections.

The poset of partial sections amounts to T⊆SubE(X)\mathcal{T}\subseteq \mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)T⊆SubE​(X) consisting of all s ⁣:M↣Xs\colon M\rightarrowtail Xs:M↣X such that ps ⁣:M→Ips\colon M\to Ips:M→I is a monomorphism. Now consider a chain (sj ⁣:Mj↣X)j∈J(s_j\colon M_j\rightarrowtail X)_{j\in J}(sj​:Mj​↣X)j∈J​ in T\mathcal{T}T. We can certainly take its union s ⁣:M↣Xs\colon M\rightarrowtail Xs:M↣X in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X). Then the question is: is it true that pspsps is mono, provided that each psjps_jpsj​ is?

The rest of the proof looks fine to me.

Soichiro Fujii said:

The poset of partial sections amounts to T⊆SubE(X)\mathcal{T}\subseteq \mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)T⊆SubE​(X) consisting of all s ⁣:M↣Xs\colon M\rightarrowtail Xs:M↣X such that ps ⁣:M→Ips\colon M\to Ips:M→I is a monomorphism. Now consider a chain (sj ⁣:Mj↣X)j∈J(s_j\colon M_j\rightarrowtail X)_{j\in J}(sj​:Mj​↣X)j∈J​ in T\mathcal{T}T. We can certainly take its union s ⁣:M↣Xs\colon M\rightarrowtail Xs:M↣X in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X). Then the question is: is it true that pspsps is mono, provided that each psjps_jpsj​ is?

Yes. The union of a chain is a filtered colimit, and since filtered colimits preserve monomorphisms, sss is also the colimit of sjs_jsj​ in E/X\mathcal{E}/XE/X. Now, composing with ppp preserves all colimits (it is left adjoint to pullback), hence pspsps is the colimit of psjp s_jpsj​ in E/I\mathcal{E}/IE/I, and so it is a monomorphism.

However, I find it slightly more intuitive to just take the union t:M→It: M \to It:M→I of the chain psjp s_jpsj​ directly. Then by the same argument this is a colimit in E/I\mathcal{E}/IE/I as well, which means you can lift it to a map s:M→Xs: M \to Xs:M→X such that ps=tps = tps=t.
Seeing non-constructive results in a text about topos theory is a little bit painful...

@Paolo Capriotti
Thank you very much! Your explanation clarified the situation greatly.

However, if I understand correctly, your argument presupposes that E\mathcal{E}E has filtered colimits...? Of course the union of a chain in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X) is a filtered colimit in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X), and (as you pointed out) it is necessarily given by a filtered colimit in E\mathcal{E}E if E\mathcal{E}E has that filtered colimit, but does it still hold even without the a priori assumption that the filtered colimit exists in E\mathcal{E}E?

Anyway, at least the immediate application of the proposition seems to be one in a Grothendieck topos, so I am satisfied for now!

@Morgan Rogers
Incidentally, the previous Proposition VI.1.7 of SGL says that a well-pointed topos is two-valued and Boolean, and is shown by a proof by contradiction...
Oof... And what a silly definition of well-pointedness too :grimacing:

@Morgan Rogers
Oh, is there any problem with the definition of well-pointedness in SGL?

Turns out I was confusing it with some other concepts (eg inhabitedness); it does match the definition of well-pointed category. But I still resent its inclusion, for the simple lack of examples; the only ones that present themselves are "inclusions of smaller universes of sets into larger ones"; that's certainly the closest thing to an example that one could get out of SGL.

What really bugs me is the fact that this result comes in a section about the axiom of choice, which is presented in both external and internal versions, but the internal version of well-pointedness isn't mentioned. :shrug:

Anyway, getting back to your question, Proposition 8 explicitly assumes completeness of Sub(E), circumventing the worry about whether E has filtered colimits.

Morgan Rogers said:

Anyway, getting back to your question, Proposition 8 explicitly assumes completeness of Sub(E), circumventing the worry about whether E has filtered colimits.

Yes, but my concern was whether the filtered colimits of chains in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X) are necessarily given by the filtered colimits in E\mathcal{E}E. Because I think the argument is like:

  • Take any chain (sj ⁣:Mj↣X)j∈J(s_j\colon M_j\rightarrowtail X)_{j\in J}(sj​:Mj​↣X)j∈J​ in T\mathcal{T}T.
  • Take the colimit M=colimj∈JMjM=\mathrm{colim}_{j\in J}M_jM=colimj∈J​Mj​ in E\mathcal{E}E; then the morphism s ⁣:M→Xs\colon M\to Xs:M→X induced by sjs_jsj​ is again a mono (*), so s∈SubE(X)s\in\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)s∈SubE​(X).
  • Similarly, the morphism ps ⁣:M→Ips\colon M\to Ips:M→I induced by psjps_jpsj​ is again a mono, so s∈Ts\in\mathcal{T}s∈T.

And to prove the third step, we use that M=colimj∈JMjM=\mathrm{colim}_{j\in J}M_j M=colimj∈J​Mj​ in E\mathcal{E}E.

(*) To be honest, I am not completely sure if (existing) filtered colimits preserve monos in any topos. I know that in a Grothendieck topos, filtered colimits exist and commute with finite limits, and hence preserve monos. Does the argument extend so that in any (elementary) topos, (existing) filtered colimits commute with finite limits?
Since here the targets of your monos are all the same (XXX), I think it follows from the fact that E/X\mathcal{E}/XE/X is cartesian closed.

Reid Barton said:

Sorry, what does “it” refer to?
That the colimit M→XM \to XM→X of a filtered diagram of monos Mj→XM_j \to XMj​→X is again a mono.

Reid Barton said:

That the colimit M→XM \to XM→X of a filtered diagram of monos Mj→XM_j \to XMj​→X is again a mono.

Hmm, maybe it is an easy thing, but I still cannot see why... Do you mean filtered colimits of subterminal objects in a cartesian closed category are always subterminal?

Soichiro Fujii said:

However, if I understand correctly, your argument presupposes that E\mathcal{E}E has filtered colimits...? Of course the union of a chain in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X) is a filtered colimit in SubE(X)\mathrm{Sub}_\mathcal{E}(X)SubE​(X), and (as you pointed out) it is necessarily given by a filtered colimit in E\mathcal{E}E if E\mathcal{E}E has that filtered colimit, but does it still hold even without the a priori assumption that the filtered colimit exists in E\mathcal{E}E?

Good point, I did assume that E\mathcal EE had filtered colimits. The missing part is that filtered colimits in Sub(X)\mathrm{Sub}(X)Sub(X) are also colimits in E/X\mathcal{E}/XE/X. Here is a direct proof, although I suspect there are more elegant ways. Let MMM be the filtered colimit of MiM_iMi​ in Sub(X)\mathrm{Sub}(X)Sub(X). It is enough to prove that MMM is the colimit of MiM_iMi​ in E\mathcal EE. So let gi:Mi→Yg_i: M_i \to Ygi​:Mi​→Y be a cocone. Our goal is to find an extension M→YM \to YM→Y (uniqueness will follow easily by taking an equaliser). Let SiS_iSi​ be the "graph" of gig_igi​, i.e. the subobject of Mi×YM_i \times YMi​×Y corresponding to the morphism gi′:Mi→Y→PYg_i': M_i \to Y \to PYgi′​:Mi​→Y→PY through the power object adjunction. Since Mi×Y→X×YM_i \times Y \to X \times YMi​×Y→X×Y is mono, SiS_iSi​ can be regarded as a suboject of X×YX \times YX×Y. Take the union SSS of those subobjects. The key fact, which uses filteredness, is that the pullback of SSS to Mi×YM_i \times YMi​×Y is SiS_iSi​. Therefore, if g′:X→PYg': X \to PYg′:X→PY is the morphism corresponding to SSS, we get that g′g'g′ restricts to gi′g_i'gi′​ for all iii. Define g:X1→Yg: X_1 \to Yg:X1​→Y by pulling back g′g'g′ along Y→PYY \to PYY→PY. Now X1→XX_1 \to XX1​→X is a monomorphism, so we get a map M→X1M \to X_1M→X1​, and composing with ggg gives the sought extension.

The argument I had in mind is the following. Suppose MMM is the filtered colimit of subterminal objects (Mj)j∈J(M_j)_{j \in J}(Mj​)j∈J​; we want to show that MMM is subterminal. It suffices to show that the projections M×M→MM \times M \to MM×M→M are isomorphisms. Now because the category is cartesian closed, we can express M×MM \times MM×M as the colimit over (j,j′)∈J×J(j, j') \in J \times J(j,j′)∈J×J of Mj×Mj′M_j \times M_{j'}Mj​×Mj′​. Because JJJ is filtered, we can replace J×JJ \times JJ×J with the cofinal diagonal subcategory JJJ, so M×MM \times MM×M is the colimit of Mj×MjM_j \times M_jMj​×Mj​. Since each MjM_jMj​ was subterminal, this is just the colimit of MjM_jMj​, which is indeed MMM.

It's the usual argument that a functor that preserves pullbacks preserves monomorphisms (test a map for being a monomorphism by pulling it back along itself), but with weaker hypotheses because, in the original formulation, the target object XXX is constant.

@Paolo Capriotti
Cool! I like how you use graphs to construct the mediating morphism. This technique seems to be worth knowing.

@Reid Barton
Okay, I got it. Thank you very much for explaining it in detail! It is also a nice result to know.
@Reid Barton nice argument! This works more generally for sifted colimits with the same proof, right?
